Use case: Use network data to curate news and content
Description: Network analytics and "triangle closure" (connecting people who are connected to common contacts) has been used extensively to drive the curation of content on social media.

Use case: Flag inappropriate content
Description: Moderation of inappropriate web content.

Who / What: DeepMind, Diffbot, Kyndi, Golden.com, Neo4J, Primer.ai, Semantic-web.com,
Use case: Understand relationships between people, objects and others
Description: It is likely that the future will see ubiquitous use of AI-augmented graph databases, a specialized field of data science that enables better analysis of connections between entities. Neo4J and Semantic-web.com are specialized players, while DeepMind, now owned by Alphabet, allows performing a “reverse Google knowledge graph” - that is, it does to people what Google does to knowledge: finding individuals who are associated with specific topics, and then people who are associated with those individuals. As another example, Diffbot is already beign used for recruiting, business intelligence, and sales & marketing – and takes a grammatic-rich approach to the problem.

Use case: Understand relations between knowledge and people
Description: Project Cortex is an application of graph database technology; it has become Microsoft Viva. It aims at optimizing the finding and sharing of relevant enterprise knowledge.

Use case: Enable content and source aggregation
Description: Mapping machines is equivalent to mapping people, at least at some basic level. Tools like Curata can help identify aggregation of relevant content, and their sources. Other curation engines that aggregate content through a combination of human and AI intervention also exist (e.g. competitive intelligence tools like XiQ.io or technologies like Discover.ai). Yet others, like Feedly, can help identify aggregation of relevant content, as well as its source. The individual person’s ability to efficiently collect and distribute curated knowledge is also the object of recent developments, for example through Factr.

Use case: Identify emergence of skills requirements in the economy
Description: Mining of job descriptions across millions of job listings

Use case: Enable match-making through sophisticated data-driven detection of affinity signals
Description: TikTok does away with people networks as a driver for curation, and cuts straight to interpreting interest in the content itself. There is Significant potential innovation in this space, possibly through smarter algorithms whose match making is based on stronger knowledge graphs interpreting affinity signals or drawing from network analytics.

Use case: Help the "collective healthcare mind remember” solutions
Description: A knowledge feeder also helps the collective mind “remember” what has worked elsewhere. For instance, medical- school instruction, or crowdsourced environments like PatientsLikeMe can help medical communities get smarter about what has worked in specific circumstances in the past, sparing the individuals the need to form those experiences directly. PatientsLikeMe is a particularly interesting example, because of their collaboration started in 2017 with Chinese AI company iCarbonX whose stated intent is to “digitize the components of life”.

Use case: Hypercurate content
Description:
Fueled by the incubation of “hypercuration” ideas made by companies like Substack and Medium, in late 2020 and early 2021, a variety of alternative models started emerging. Forums like Clubhouse and Twitter Super Follows showed that smaller audiences, relying on a more intimate connection with the creators, could also be financially attractive and, hopefully, yield more thoughtful, insightful, and civil information feeders.
At the end of 2020, the introduction of Clubhouse created a new hybrid: real-time audio-only conversations, in private invite-only rooms, where (typically) influencers host discussion in which participants can raise hand and intervene. This one-to-many model is de-facto a hybrid between social media (podcasting) and unified communications. While it is too early to tell if this model would be effective, in early 2021 Clubhouse was already valued as a Unicorn.

Use case: Store and retrieve all world news
Description: To tap into news trends, G-DELT, a global database of published sources, auto-translated from dozens of languages and available as a public resource or through Google Big Query is a great resource. The globally- sourced news repository G-DELT disgorges machine-translated news from thousands of publicly accessible sources worldwide. It has the ability to identify newsworthy actions taken by billions of people: from adaptation to water scarcity, to early detection of potential conflicts due to environmental stress, to surfacing of the perceived popularity and adoption of public policies, the world becomes a petri dish that teams elsewhere can read, avoiding the proverbial reinvention of the wheel.

Use case: Monitor the online content production
Description: Listening posts can be created, typically through social media tools like Feedly, Hootsuite, and Tweetdeck, but also by giving internal users, typically subject matter experts, the ability to act as “level-1 curators” who, by virtue of their own network, can act as initial filters that complement the listening posts.

Use case: Enable a search engine for environmental data and resources
Description: Some search engines are customizable and can be turned into usefully curated sources. Dataplanet is a customizable search engine that focuses on environmental data and resources, like WRI.org.

Use case: Enable analysis of complex, distributed web based information
Description: With the advances in Natural Language Processing, machines are getting better at helping humans make sense of connections between elements of large content sets – as in the example of Quid.com or Forestreet that can map technology market landscapes and draw connections between market participants and related technologies

Use case: Identify patterns in scientific literature for Covid19
Description: In 2020, BenevolentAI came into the limelight for using machine learning and other AI techniques to identify patterns in existing literature through knowledge graphs. As stated on their website “in the face of the growing global health crisis, BenevolentAI set up a specialist scientific team and launched an investigation using its drug discovery platform to identify approved drugs which could potentially stop the progression of COVID-19, inhibit the cytokine storm and reduce the inflammatory damage associated with this disease. Benevolent’s research findings were published in [scientific journals] as a potential treatment with both anti-viral and anti-inflammatory properties, for COVID-19 patients admitted to hospital prior to the development of critical lung damage.”

Use case: Discover trends through knowledge graphs and automated data exploration
Description: SparkBeyond launched in 2019 an automated data exploration technology that sifts through multiple data sources (web, patents, news etc.) and visualizes ideas that are connected to each other (co-occurring entities), hence facilitating the mining of potential solutions to existing problems: think about being able to quickly query that global corpus of knowledge, largely a curation of human-generated ideas, to find solutions to pressing problems – from disposal of plastics to reducing fossil-fuel energy consumptions for residential cooling. Quid.com, iProva and Forestreet work in similar spaces.

Who / What: Factmata.com, fullfact.org, Disinformation Lab, Citizen Evidence Lab, Snopes.com
Use case: Check facts
Description: Bolster fact-checking platforms in a partly automated fashion using natural language analysis and network-credibility analytics such as Factmata.com or fullfact.org, the European Union’s Disinformation Lab, Amnesty International’s Citizen Evidence Lab which collects and compares additional metadata (such as location, weather), Snopes.com, or partly crowdsourced

Use case: Summarize content
Description: Enabling the consumption of larger quantities of information by people

Use case: Annotate geographic features
Description: Readily available satellite pictures helped students identify ballistic missiles silos being built in China, by leveraging Geo4Nonpro’s community infrastructure

Use case: Monitor media
Description: Use of knowledge graphs to curate media sources (in English)

Use case: Provide early warning of a crisis
Description: In conflict zones airstrikes have devastating consequences – causing civilian deaths and injuries on a massive scale. Densely populated neighbourhoods, hospitals, schools or other locations with high levels of civilians are often targets for strikes. It is challenging to predict when strikes will occur, and to issue time-critical warnings enabling civilians to seek safety from imminent attacks. What is the CCI solution? Sentry, developed by social enterprise Hala Systems, is an indication and warning system that uses a multi-sensor network to generate a real-time awareness of threats and quickly disseminate warnings. Sentry uses acoustic sensor data, reports from people on-the-ground and open media ‘scraping’ to detect warplanes in flight. It then uses artificial intelligence (AI) to validate information from multiple sources, and issues warnings to civilians and global stakeholders. Combining the intelligence of local community actors with a wide range of additional data sources and AI enables Sentry to give accurate warnings to affected civilians and stakeholders. How is it being done? Sentry combines a number of  sensing’ data sources, including data captured by sensors that detect the sound of military aircraft and reports from volunteer “plane spotters” who live near air bases and in conflict zones to predict when and where air strikes will occur. The volunteer “plane spotter” network was an early grassroot response to airstrikes in Syria made up of trusted civilian contacts (including teachers,  ngineers, doctors, farmers). Plane spotters work in shifts and watch for planes, recording information in a smartphone app. Sentry combines this with data from remote acoustic sensors hidden in trees and tall buildings and data scraped from social and local media (by a machine learning algorithm) to confirm information about the plane and flight path. The ‘sensing’ data inputs are  alidated by an AI-based model trained on historical data; the software estimates the possible target and timing of the airstrike by comparing it to past cases of attacks. Sentry then issues alerts to citizens in affected areas five to ten minutes in advance of an airstrike to give them time to escape. Warnings are disseminated through social media (including via chat bots), TV, radio and  n-theground sirens, and direct messages are sent to local civil society organisations, hospitals and schools. Sentry uses blockchain technology to immutably store war crime information and citizen reports collected through the tool. (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case:
Provide real-time situational
information for more effective response
Description:
The widespread use of mobile phones means that many people involved in disasters publish information-rich textual and multimedia messages on social media networks, often live and in situ. Following a crisis, both natural or man-made, this data can be used to generate a situational awareness of the event and aftermath, to help governments, aid agencies and other organisations to respond. However, relevant information from social media is typically unstructured, heterogeneous and fragmented over many messages, in such a way that it cannot be directly used. Extracting and processing vast volumes of data quickly and effectively is of paramount importance for supporting emergency crisis relief efforts. What is the CCI solution?
HERMES is a CI tool developed by the Italian National Research Council which enriches available social media data in the aftermath of disasters by identifying relevant Tweets and automatically asking follow-up questions to garner more detailed information from the person who posted the message. It leverages the collective intelligence of affected populations and wider citizens by using socialmedia data posted in crisis events, and applies AI to effectively process the data and maximise  utility. How is it being done? HERMES automatically complements spontaneously published data (i.e. a Tweet) with targeted solicited data by asking the person who posted the Tweet specific questions to gather further detailed information. The system listens to the stream of social media messages related to a disaster. Then, it leverages AI techniques to select a subset of relevant social media users directly involved in the disaster, from which to solicit additional information. HERMES automatically asks targeted questions to selected users, and it collects answers to those questions in real-time. Finally, relevant information obtained via message classification or information extraction is often leveraged to produce and update crisis maps, and shared with Emergency Operation Centers. (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Keep tabs on elected officials' agenda
Description: www.theyworkforyou.com enables citizens in the UK to be kept informed about the statements and action made by their democratically elected officials in a simple way. Equivalent systems have been developed for other parts of the world. Similar objective as Canada's Trudeaau Meter that monitors the premier's delivery on his commitments. And Germany's abgeordnetenwatch.de

Use case: Alert the right authorities of local problems
Description: https://fixmystreet.com enables citizens to easily alert the right organizations for local level problems, based on the type of problem and location. Active in the UK. Objective similar to SeeClickFix platform that helps citizens and towns identify issues at scale and route them for faster processing.

Use case: Harness large database of satellite imagery for data science
Description: Google Earth Engine combines a multi-petabyte catalog of satellite imagery and geospatial datasets with planetary-scale analysis capabilities. Scientists, researchers, and developers use Earth Engine to detect changes, map trends, and quantify differences on the Earth's surface. Earth Engine is available for commercial use, and remains free for academic and research use. (Source: Google)

Use case: Use UI changes to boost curation of relevant content
Description: One of the most significant improvement in people's ability to share web and social media content has been the introduction of standard "share with" icons that can be used from web pages, documents etc. Making the sharing into people and applications frictionless has greatly increased the amount of human-based curation of web knowledge.

Use case: Use fashion memes to influence trends
Description: New fashion items, when visible associated with influential people, travel across networks. That propagation is often of the "simple contagion" type, in that even a single exposure to the new items is sufficient to generate demand for it in a new person (see Damon Centola for more). Social media has created a platform for amplification of these signals. The actual value in making the collective behavior of the community more effectively adaptive depends on the influencers (think of second hand fashion vs fast fashion). Fashionable items typically foster a sense of belonging which in itself is an incentive for people in that specific community.

Use case: Aggregate news sources to cover emerging situations
Description: LiveUAmap overlays disparate and timely news sources on a map to provide better coverage of emerging situations eg for the Ukraine crisis in 2022.

Use case: Leak documents through social media
Description: Julian Assanges founded controversial WikiLeaks is as international non-profit organisation that publishes news leaks and classified media provided by anonymous sources. Its website, initiated in 2006 in Iceland by the organisation Sunshine Press, stated in 2015 that it had released online 10 million documents in its first 10 years.

Use case: Monitor sanctions during Ukraine's war through knowledge graphs
Description: Knowledge graph technology from Diffbot was used to monitor the impact of Western sanctions on specific companies, by surfacing and recombining natural language data from news and other web based sources.

Use case: Nurture communities of experts that complement in-house customer interaction teams
Description: Nurture communities of experts that complement your in-house customer interaction teams. Use deep semantic analysis to understand trends. Ensure that product management teams are connected in a bi-directional way so that they can learn from new queries and help create knowledge artifacts to feed the distributed problem solvers.

Use case: Identify patterns from a content corpus, that humans can further assess
Description: Semantic searches and computer vision that identify the most relevant content (whether text or visual) and cluster it for people to process it more easily; automated data discovery which combs through multidimensional data sets to identify patterns that humans would take too long to evince; combine knowledge as in the field of generative design where human intelligence completes the selection of hybrid ideas generated by machines.

Use case: Enable distributed geospatial data tagging
Description: Ubiquitous infrastructure enabling distributed geospatial tagging. Crowdsourced sensor data used by citizen scientists can use GPS signals.

Use case: Crowdsource biosphere (land) monitoring
Description: Crowdsourced sensor data used by machines; computer vision sifting through mixed-source imagery to improve agricultural decisions.

Use case: Crowdsource geospatial mapping
Description: Crowdsourced sensor data used by citizen scientists.

Use case: Produce human-assisted geospatial and traffic mapping
Description: Crowdsourced sensor data from users, processed and delivered back to end users in a more usable format.

Use case: Use RFID devices to map in-person interactions
Description: By mapping the semantic network beyond the obvious words, we also find new people that can help generate novel solutions. These two steps can be performed in the broader world, by mining social media and other available sources, but also within an individual company. When connections between people in physical environments are important, in-person interactions can be mapped through RFID devices such as the one from MIT-spinoff Humanyze.

Use case: Understand business processes
Description: It is possible that users of business process mining technology will increasingly utilize social network analysis to complement their workflow analyses.

Use case: Use email data to identify networks of people and knowledge
Description: To map relevant people and “illuminate” the external network we first need to precisely define the language for topics of interest which can be disambiguated through what is called “entity extraction”, which helps identify the semantic field, i.e. the words, that reflect that theme – for instance “artificial intelligence” and “machine learning” and “neural network” would be branches and separate entities. The next step is some social media scraping and searching for connections or followers of initial nodal people. For instance, experts in reskilling would likely follow a few dozen core experts in that field. Having a database of key people can help connecting them.

Use case: Internet media scraper
Description: To map relevant people and “illuminate” the external network we first need to precisely define the language for topics of interest which can be disambiguated through what is called “entity extraction”, which helps identify the semantic field, i.e. the words, that reflect that theme – for instance “artificial intelligence” and “machine learning” and “neural network” would be branches and separate entities. The next step is some social media scraping and searching for connections or followers of initial nodal people. For instance, experts in reskilling would likely follow a few dozen core experts in that field. Having a database of key people can help connecting them.

Use case: Improve Citizen and Employee engagement
Description: Glint, now owned by LinkedIn, is a survey platform to measure employee engagement. Pol.is and TINYpulse are other examples of people survey platforms. Keencorp, operating in the same field, makes greater use of SNA.Other examples are Parti (civic engagement in South Korea), Swae.io (bottom-up engagement and ideation), consultproject.org (free software for citizen participation), Civocracy.com and MindMixer (community engagement)

Use case: Scale the Mapping and sharing of observations of biodiversity
Description: The iNaturalist community (an effort run by the California Academy of Science and the National Geographic Society) uses specialized computer vision specialized classifiers to allow the mapping and sharing of observations of biodiversity across the globe using a free mobile app and has contributed more than 60 million observations of more than 300,00 species.

Use case: Track biodiversity degradation
Description: In the UK, a network of sensors tracks biodiversity degradation.

Use case: Map human responses to adverse weather events
Description:
The Mexican state of Tabasco has been mapping human behavior in response to adverse weather events, combining mobile and other sensor data, to pinpoint needs and interventions. The effort is part of the “UN Global Pulse”, harnessing support from the respective UN agency, the World Food Program, and local constituencies. 
A comparable effort is at play in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, where the Ramani Huria project, (based on OpenStreetMap – an open sourced mapping effort), helps local communities map relevant infrastructure and land features especially in informal human settlements.

Use case: Use image recognition software for biosphere tracking (animals in the wild)
Description: Oregon-based Wild Me's software provides image recognition to cameras positioned in the wild – so that individuals can be tracked as they move in their habitat.

Use case: Generate Multisourced / crowdsourced maps for healthcare
Description: Healthmap.org “delivers real-time intelligence on a broad range of emerging infectious diseases for a diverse audience including libraries, local health departments, governments, and international travelers. HealthMap brings together disparate data sources, including online news aggregators, eyewitness reports, expert- curated discussions and validated official reports, to achieve a unified and comprehensive view of the current global state of infectious diseases and their effect on human and animal health. Through an automated process, updating 24/7/365, the system monitors, organizes, integrates, filters, visualizes and disseminates online information about emerging diseases in nine languages, facilitating early detection of global public health threats.”

Use case: Perform investigative journalism
Description: Bellingcat uses crowdsourced information for investigative journalism. It also runs workshops to train people on using web resources for research investigation.

Use case: Search companies or topics, supported by humans in the review workflow
Description: golden.com that provides accurate semantic search on companies or topics of interest, for use in consulting, investment or financial services for example. The company Golden in particular has emphasized the synergy between machine and human curators, by enabling workflows allowing editors to improve content quality.

Use case: Identify the position of individuals or assets through digital means
Description: Geofencing is the practice of identifying the physical position of an individual or asset through digital means (for instance mobile phone GPS), and monitoring its position to detect trespassing and trigger additional action (such as notifying people at vicinity, or security forces).

Use case: Coordinate insurgencies' military operations
Description: The takeover of Afghanistan in 2021 by the Taliban is a somber reminder of how effective the pervasive use of comparatively simple collaboration technology (in this case, WhatsApp groups) can be.

Use case: Use genomic surveillance networks to detect Covid-19 variants
Description: When additional variants of the virus started to emerge, genomic surveillance networks across the world proved invaluable – for instance, the Africa Pathogen Genomics Initiative, first established to track Ebola and yellow fever. [Source: Azeem Azhar, "Exponential"]

Use case: Detect spread of locusts
Description: Mercicorps’ Agrifin provides a platform for African countries to use multiple sources, including crowdsourced input, to detect the spread of locusts

Use case: Predict a crisis before it happens
Description: Dengue is a mosquito-borne infection and major international public health concern, with severe dengue affecting many Asian and Latin American countries and up to 2.5 billion people worldwide. A major challenge in many dengue endemic countries is that disease surveillance is often passive and reliant on case reporting by health workers, meaning it can be difficult to ensure completeness and timeliness of data. Often dengue outbreaks have occurred or even passed their peak before they are registered by systems. Time delays and poor predictive capability mean that public health officials are missing vital opportunities for disease control and to implement a timely localised response. Predicting outbreaks is of paramount importance as there is no treatment to prevent or stop dengue, and the WHO recommends that the vaccine only be given to persons with confirmed prior dengue virus infection, thereby leaving large swathes of the population in disease endemic countries at risk.  What is the CCI solution? Artificial intelligence in Medical Epidemiology (AIME) is an early warning system incorporating AI to identify and forecast dengue outbreaks with a high accuracy and spatial precision. AIME leverages the intelligence of local doctors and healthcare professionals and combines this with a wide range of data sources and machine learning to predict (and therefore prevent) disease outbreak.  AIME uses real-time data generated by doctors, who send in notifications of dengue cases via AIME’s subsystem (REDINT); this can be accessed by hospitals within a community/ region, enabling them to immediately update and report dengue cases to the public health municipality. Case data is combined with existing datasets of variables that influence the spread of dengue – from local terrain and elevation to roofing types and thunderstorms, as well as official data about the local population and socioeconomic variables. The AIME platform combines data and uses a machine learning algorithm in order to predict, geo-locate and determine future outbreaks. The platform enables surveillance of current disease outbreaks, by determining their exact location, and can forecast future outbreaks. (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Provide real-time situational information for more effective response
Description: During a natural disaster, access to accurate, consistent and timely information can be limited. This can slow, and sometimes prevent, responders from acting and collaborating in a crisis. As a result, different response efforts may be using different datasets and information, and therefore not supporting the communities most in need. What is the CCI solution? MIND is an automated open source platform created by UN Global Pulse that collects and processes data from a range of sources and presents this data through a single aggregated platform that all responders can use when coordinating response to a natural disaster. How is it being done? The platform is built on an automated data pipeline (using a number of APIs), allowing it to stream and analyse several non-traditional data sets all in one place. This includes data generated by affected communities local to the incident taking place and scraped from Twitter and Google searches, as well as information from Wikipedia and OpenStreetMap about the location, casualty reports from news sources, and data from the International Aid Transparency Initiative, showing details about projects and organisations in the affected areas. The automated collection and processing of the data is triggered based on disaster alerts received from the Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS), which is a global system aimed at closing information and coordination gaps.

Use case: Provide real-time situational information for more effective response
Description: For 15 years, thousands of volunteers have used OpenStreetMap (OSM) to create a free and open map of the world. The community of mappers help build OSM by adding manually captured data, importing and reviewing open public data or official data (such as satellite images) and annotating features like roads, highways and bridges. While mappers may be remote, local communities can also use the tool to map their local neighbourhoods. Despite the popularity of OSM, many areas remain unmapped, unvalidated or incorrectly labelled. This is mostly because crowd annotation of maps is time- and labourintensive for volunteers and finding an equivalent number of real-life validators is difficult. Maps are not static – particularly in vulnerable regions affected by conflict (such as where borders may be disputed) and environmental crises – so they may require remapping if an area experiences rapid changes in infrastructure. These areas need constant monitoring, which is difficult to achieve manually. Accurate maps play an essential role in crisis situations by supporting the response efforts of frontline workers, aid organisations, national and international government bodies by helping them to understand the scale of impact, and effectively target and coordinate relief. What is the CCI solution? The Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team (HOT) is a dedicated community that uses OSM to support responses to crises, such as urban floods and migration, by mapping vulnerable regions. In 2018, HOT launched the MapWithAI initiative (in partnership with Facebook) which elevates the collective intelligence of volunteers by using artificial intelligence (AI) to drive the speed, efficiency and scale of mapping efforts. How is it being done? MapWithAI uses computer vision to detect roads and terrain features of the streets on high-resolution satellite imagery. Trained using years of volunteer-labelled satellite data, complex patterns in images are identified by an algorithm known as a deep neural network segmentation model. This model estimates the probability that each pixel is part of a road, predicts and draws potential roads, and generates an enhanced image for the volunteer community through an editing tool called RapiD. Using RapiD, volunteers verify the AI generated roads, helping to identify errors in the model and contribute to its improvement. The project initially focused on the response to flooding in Kerala, India, but has since been integrated into the HOT volunteer-management platform for deployment on other projects. Project managers and volunteers can opt-in to use the tool or continue mapping without it. Using RapiD, volunteers are able to create maps of disaster affected regions more quickly. Projects carried out through the HOT task manager platform draw on contributions from a wide range of participants including local volunteers and frontline responders, particularly for validation of remote mapping efforts. (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Predict a crisis before it happens in Colombia
Description: Over one million people die a year from mosquito borne diseases, and in 2016, the city of Cali in Colombia suffered the second largest Zika virus outbreak in the world as a result of a lack of data and control on mosquito populations. To prevent and limit these outbreaks, a vast amount of data is required to identify and remove breeding grounds, such as standing water. Monitoring locations across a city or region is a laborious process that requires a large number of people to regularly collect data. What is the CCI solution? Utilising a citizen network in and around the city of Cali, the Premise platform provided a tool to allow affected communities to crowdsource data and monitor conditions in hard-to-reach geographies. Citizens are trained through the Premise app and offered micropayments as incentives to collect data, which can then be visualised for authorities to monitor and respond to mosquito breeding sites. The platform also enables a collective mitigation response by informing citizens of best practice in vector surveillance and control. How is it being done? The Premise crowdsource platform relies on a four step process: configure, collect, quality control and visualise. First, the city authority and Premise community managers establish the questions that need to be asked to the citizen network to collect the data that is required for a targeted response. This is configured into the platform with appropriate instructions to ensure a consistency and quality to data collection. The citizen contributors’ network then begin collecting data, incentivised through behavioural nudges and micropayments, and upload the data to the Premise platform. Premise utilises AI to quality control the uploaded data and identify any false or duplicative entries. Finally, this data is visualised on the Premise platform for both the community and authorities to work together to identify and remove potential breeding grounds. (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case:
Provide real-time situational
information for more effective response
Description: When a natural disaster strikes, such as Typhoon Lando (Koppu) in the Philippines, it can be challenging for affected communities to communicate with first responders about the scale of the disaster and the support that is required. Equally, first responders, operational  managers and government agencies often use a multitude of data sources to coordinate response that do not always reflect the support needs of affected groups. What is the CCI solution? eBayanihan is a muti-channel platform that enables citizens to view and upload reports of natural disasters and community needs, providing a direct link to first responders, operational managers and government agencies. Citizens are therefore able to express the support that is  equired in their affected communities, rather than responders focusing on the mapped impact of the natural disaster. First responders, operational managers and government agencies therefore have a single source of data that informs how to target their response, visualised through a dashboard and interactive map. How is it being done? Affected communities uploaded citizen reports (CitReports) that describe the damage caused by Typhoon Lando, as well as the needs of the community, such as shelter, food and water via multiple channels including SMS, web and an app. Machine learning algorithms help to model and validate these crowdsourced CitReports – categorising and visualising them for operational teams to respond to. These feed into a real-time dashboard visualising incidents and automating notifications to people managing, responding to or coordinating the response of natural disasters.  (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Crowdsource database and foster community for environmental restoration
Description: Restor is a science-based open data platform to support and connect the global restoration movement, accelerating the global restoration movement by connecting everyone, everywhere to local restoration. Restor connects people to scientific data, supply chains, funding, and each other to increase the impact, scale, and sustainability of restoration efforts. Participants can Analyse restoration potential for any area anywhere, Monitor and manage all their restoration projects in one place, Share projects to show progress and support the movement, and Connect with the movement (e.g. Explore sites locally and globally, Find potential partners doing similar work, Search using a range of scientific and social filters, Share contact information to connect directly with other users.)

Use case: Use open data for economic for modeling and forecast
Description: The ubiquity of sensors, combined with the availability of machine learning and other computationally sophisticated methods and infrastructure, is also bound to change the field of economics. GDP measurement is a hierarchical effort, lacks granularity and speed, and is subject to significant manual intervention. Information like restaurant booking OpenTable can help surface early signals to sense changing conditions and inform trend estimates in ways that were previously impossible.

Use case: Channel messages from citizens to their representatives
Description: www.writetothem.com helps citizens contact their elected representatives to pressure them on important issues and generally keep them accountable for their role in democratic representation

Use case: Decentralize a network of sensors, distributing air pollution data
Description: Run by UNEP and Swiss technology company IQAir, GEMS is the largest air pollution network in the world, covering some 5,000 cities. In 2020, over 50 million users accessed the platform and its data is being streamed into digital billboards to alert people about air quality risks in real time. In the future, the program aims to extend this capability directly into mobile phone health applications.

Use case: Enable open-source mapping of power generation and other energy intensive plants
Description: Wiki based https://globalenergymonitor.org/ enable energy analysts, scientists, activists by pinpointing coal and gas plants globally, as well as wind, steel etc. Data includes capital flows and progress of building those capital assets

Use case: Collect data for research
Description: Mozilla's Firefox plugin "put your data to work to help Mozilla and research partners address (e.g. university researchers) areas such as ethical AI, online privacy, algorithmic bias, discrimination, and misinformation." It is called "Dataraising"

Use case: Open-source peer reviewed scientific research
Description: The US Public Library of Science launched in early 2022 a freely accessible journal supported by a global editorial board with the mission of sharing some of the best and most important climate research (https://journals.plos.org/climate/) and offer a conduit for the dissemination of interdisciplinary work that crosses the boundaries of traditional disciplinary siloes.

Use case: Use NFTs to create forestation registries
Description: Openforestprotocol.org is a community of climate change forestation project operators, validators and funders that uses blockchain technology for its records and transactions. Of particular note is the storage of immutable land-registry forestry records (including validated location, representative imagery) as non-fungible Ethereum blockchain tokens (NFTs).

Use case: Crowdsource military radar tracking
Description: The open-source Radar Interference Tracker (RIT) allows anyone to search for and potentially locate active military radar systems anywhere on earth. The Bellingcat Investigative Tech Team (part of investigative community Bellingcat) has also published the source code for the RIT tool on it on its Github page.

Use case: Monitor animal behavior to forewarn of impeding natural disasters
Description: Scientists have found that certain species of animals are able to sense the impending arrival of a natural disruption, such as an earthquake or a tornado. Experiments are apace trying to combine biologged signals from different animals in different locations to triangulate the possible riskiest areas, possibly in combination with other instrumental measurements.

Use case: Provide open-access data about fishing impact
Description: A decade ago, building an open-access picture of global fishing activity was out of reach. But thanks to advances in satellite technology and machine learning, Global Fishing Watch is now making it a reality.

Use case: Crowdsource sexual violence reports
Description: Safecity is a platform that empowers individuals, communities, police and city government to create safer public and private spaces. Its technology stack collects and analyses crowdsourced, anonymous reports of sexual violence, identifying patterns and key insights.

Use case: Inform policy through collective forecasting
Description: INFER is a community of researchers, analysts, and passionate forecasters that inform U.S. Government policymaking by generating signals and early warning about the future of science and technology trends and events.

Use case: Map UK trees
Description: Interactive, crowdsourced map of tree assets and their positive impact

Use case: Harness indigenous knowledge
Description: Inuit ice knowledge combined with geospatial data. Community driven mapping of ice conditions and interpretation of related risks, to increase safety https://en.unesco.org/courier/2019-1/siku-mixing-high-tech-ancient-know-how

Use case: Enable community driven weather watch in Colorado
Description: CoCoRaHS "is a grassroots volunteer network of backyard weather observers of all ages and backgrounds working together to measure and map precipitation (rain, hail and snow) in their local communities. By using low-cost measurement tools, stressing training and education, and utilizing an interactive Web-site, our aim is to provide the highest quality data for natural resource, education and research applications."

Use case: Identify corrupted public officials
Description: Crowdsourced, anonymized surfacing of instances of bribes encountered by citizens in India when dealing with their public services providers

Use case: Use administrative data for estimating census
Description: Census Transformation Programme (New Zealand) used administrative data to provide an alternative method of producing a census (source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Help the organ-donation market clear
Description: OrganJet provides an information service, as well as options for timely and affordable air transport, for patients who are multi-listed or distant listed for organ transplants in the U.S.

Use case: Aggregate air quality data
Description: Plume's technologies provide air quality information for any location —getting right down to street level in over 100 major cities around the world. They draw on over 12,000 monitoring stations and own models, integrating a large amount of data including weather information, population density, land-use and road networks.

Use case: Detect diseases and disruption outbreaks
Description: Bluedot collates and analyzes sources such as local news and other databases, in order to identify emerging health risks such as pandemics.

Use case: Provide environmental data through a decentralized web3 platform
Description: dClimate is a transparent, decentralized marketplace where climate data, forecasts, and models are standardized, monetized, and distributed. The marketplace connects data publishers directly with data consumers, making climate data more accessible and reliable. When data providers share data and forecasts with the market it is automatically scored for reliability, which helps consumers to shop for information. In exchange, dClimate creates a simple, direct-to-consumer distribution mechanism to monetize their work. dClimate's base layer is built on Ethereum, and the network leverages Chainlink's leading decentralized oracle network to  facilitate on-chain validation and support for dClimate's governance layer. dClimate starts on day one with a foundation of dozens of terabytes of standardized climate data ready for institutional use and anchor-client Arbol, a leading parametric weather risk platform.

Use case: Detect species exctinction risk
Description: https://www.frogid.net.au/ empowers volunteers in the field to log sightings, so that other volunteers can study patterns that might hold clues on the depletion of natural stock of frogs.

Use case: Crowdsleuthing
Description: Distributed Denial of Secrets (ddosecrets.com) is a journalist 501(c)(3) non-profit devoted to enabling the free transmission of data in the public interest. It was involved in the assessment of the role of right wing platform Parler in the occupation of US Capital after Joe Biden's election to US President.

Use case: Form stronger social bonds in physical spaces
Description: Zenly is a mobile social app that helps users map their locations, and those of their friends, to make them meet more easily and curate information about their location habits. The aggregation of the information provides a unique user experience to the members.

Use case: Share climate relevant data sets
Description: DClimate.net is a marketplace of decentralized climate data for data science work. It uses Ethereum to enable buying/selling transactions. -

Use case: Predict the stock market
Description: Social media app Stocktiwts is in many ways similar to Twitter focuses on stocks, and features private rooms where influencers can guide individual investors.

Use case: Learn relevant, emerging facts
Description: The prioritization and display of information on a LinkedIn feed combines community- driven signals with other information intended to analyze the engagement that specific content generates.

Use case: Improve patients therapy by combining human practices through machine learning
Description: The Human Diagnosis Project (Human Dx) is a worldwide effort created with and led by the global medical community to build an online system that maps the steps to help any patient. By combining collective intelligence with machine learning, Human Dx intends to enable more accurate, affordable, and accessible care for all. "Let's end unequal access to medical knowledge" is their motto.

Use case: Collect information and help employees collaborate
Description: In many companies, the foundation of a collective knowledge feeder already exists through the convergence of three things: electronic communications, especially email and more recent collaboration environments like Slack or Microsoft Teams or, in open communities, tools like Circle; organizational structures that include subject matter expert s, e.g. practice leaders in consulting firms; and pervasive information feeds fueled by the explosion of internet-based knowledge sharing from social media to specifically curated knowledge feeds.

Use case: Flag inappropriate content
Description: Crowdsourced sensor data used by machines.

Use case: Access the world's knowledge
Description: Wolfram Alpha uses smarter, AI based, semantic analysis to understand language and return the right information from an openly-accessible corpus. Wolfram Alpha relies on both semantics and curated, structured data derived from internet data sources. The new generation of search engines uses smarter, AI based, semantic analysis to understand language and return the right information.

Use case: Post recommendation in professional-use social media
Description: Social media sites like LinkedIn and Twitter likely walk a tightrope between prioritizing content for our viewing from weak-tie and strong-tie connections. It seems plausible that at some point people will have the ability to customize settings, so they can get exposed to more of one or the other.

Use case: Identify entities in data structures
Description: To map relevant people and “illuminate” the external network we first need to precisely define the language for topics of interest which can be disambiguated through what is called “entity extraction”, which helps identify the semantic field, i.e. the words, that reflect that theme – for instance “artificial intelligence” and “machine learning” and “neural network” would be branches and separate entities. The next step is some social media scraping and searching for connections or followers of initial nodal people. For instance, experts in reskilling would likely follow a few dozen core experts in that field. Having a database of key people can help connecting them.

Use case: Scraping social media to find war equipment
Description: The Syrian Archive is an initiative using tools that scrapes social media feeds to detect and classify imagery pertaining to war equipment, with the intent of documenting and making searchable evidence of war crimes. The neural net AI curates and classifies information automatically.

Use case: Analyze markets
Description: CB Insights is a natural language processing engine that uses advanced analytics; it monitors the venture-capital backed startup space and aggregates insights across company news

Use case: Curate news
Description: Curation engines that aggregate content through a combination of human and AI intervention also exist (e.g., Curata but also competitive intelligence tools like XiQ.io or technologies like Discover.ai). The individual person’s ability to efficiently collect and distribute curated knowledge is also the object of recent developments, for example through Factr.

Use case: Discover opinions among city dwellers
Description: Citibeats.net have specialized in mining people’s opinion to help cities and public organizations extract insights from their constituencies.

Use case: Scan entire documents and finds relevant materials irrespective of their links to other websites
Description: Omnity.io challenges’ the premise of Google’s traditional search (based on citations and connections) to enhance the search of relevant information. Omnity doesn’t need keywords, as it is able to scan entire documents (for example, research notes) and find relevant materials on the web, irrespective of the amount of links to other websites. While Google has enhanced its search engines through knowledge graphs that enable semantic search, its algorithms still significantly reliy on web links because of the advertising value of well-connected web real estate.

Use case: Analyze scientific and innovation literature and detect of patterns
Description: US Department of Energy’s Berkeley National Lab used NLP to create word-based bodies of text vectors in its word2vec (machine learning) algorithm, which proved to be able to predict material science’s advances

Use case: Democratize natural language analysis, resulting in better search and trend analysis etc.
Description: Enablers of hyperconnectivity rarely use artificial intelligence on natural language for anything more than basic search, grammar and spellcheck. This is a gap, given the important role that language plays in enabling large groups of people to innovate and learn together. Natural language processing (NLP) however has improved the ability for people to exchange large knowledge sets, by enabling for instance better search functions. Tools like EyeOnText simplify data science on text analytics. Text “x-ray” like what’s done by Amazon Kindle allow the automatic creation of themes that humans can peruse and recombine.

Use case: Search curated web information
Description: Semantic MediaWiki “is a free, open-source extension to MediaWiki – the wiki software that powers Wikipedia – that lets you store and query data within the wiki's pages”. Semantic web where knowledge can be assembled, mapped, tagged, structured to search for content in a more effective way

Use case: Search curated web information
Description: “The Underlay is a global, distributed graph of public knowledge. [...] This is an attempt to replicate the richness of private knowledge graphs in a public, decentralized manner." Semantic web where knowledge can be assembled, mapped, tagged, structured to search for content in a more effective way.

Use case: Limit spreading of falsehoods on social media
Description: Singapore’s government in 2019 enforced regulations that require labeling of social network posts that spread falsehoods, for example. During the Covid-19 pandemic, social media tagged misinformation, partially with the help of users who surfaced suspicious information early. In general, research has shown that relatively small groups of laypeople can identify factual bias from small amounts of text, such as titles and subtitles, which bodes well for machine-enhanced crowdsourcing of fact checking.

Use case: Moderate and limit bias of social media content
Description: AI only knows what it is taught by the data it is fed and how it is trained on that data. Bias can creep into both. For example, AI learns bias if the sample data inadvertently excludes certain ethnicities, or if a small AI team passes on its own bias. AI deployment for network information should have processes and governance that minimize mistakes leading to bias. Facebook, for instance, is starting down this path with its content moderation oversight body.

Use case: Use flight data for decentralized analysis
Description: Routes of airplanes (e.g., through FlightRadar24) and ships are available publicly, which adds data to understand, among others, CO2 emissions sources.

Use case: Discover Weekly to encourage diversity in media consumption
Description: To prevent media bubbles, we can rework the algorithms for instance by introducing rules that limit the amount of unproven information they feed to large groups, or force serendipity into the choices of content served (an example of this is Spotify Discover Weekly functionality that can encourage exploration beyond one’s comfort zone)

Use case: Consolidate data from multiple blockchain governances
Description: Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO), withTally is a voting dashboard to aggregate information from disparate Defi governance structures such as Compound or Uniswap;

Use case: Curate startup knowledge
Description: Founders, funders, creatives, and creators need a dedicated place to collect and connect the dots. Startupy plans to be a community-powered database for startup knowledge, organized associatively. Startupy would incentivize experts to contribute startup knowledge and gain an internet-wide reputation in specific domains.

Use case: Inventory and query science documentation
Description: Microsoft Academic Graph (MAG) - is a scientific database with more than 236M documents

Use case: Publish a web-based, open, peer-reviewed scientific journal
Description: First Monday is one of the first openly accessible, peer–reviewed journals on the Internet, solely devoted to the Internet. Since its start in May 1996 and as of early 2022, First Monday has published 2,133 papers in 309 issues, written by 3,107 different authors.

Use case: Research biology through open database of proteome data
Description: OpenCell is a proteome-scale collection of protein localization and interaction measurements in human cells made thanks to CRISPR technology. It is built upon a library of 1,310 endogenously-tagged HEK293T cell lines that enables researchers to observe both protein localization (using live-cell fluorescence microscopy) and protein-protein interactions (using IP-MS) in the same cellular context.

Use case: Research topics through AI
Description: Search engines don't structure research topics well, but other NLP tools like Gyan.ai attempt to provide richer content quality by using a combination of web and database search, and knowledge graph technology.

Use case: Decentralize brand building
Description: So-called headless brands are increasingly important in consumer products, especially fashion and apparel. Decentralized, independent producers and influencers bypass or complement established brands and their marketing. Infrastructure like Metafactory helps them organize - throughout their supply chain, and thanks to crypto assets such as NFTs (non fungible tokens).

Use case: Summarizing the insights for climate change science
Description: The IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change) report, for instance its major 2022 release, is a global effort to summarize the entire scientific fact base around climate science, in an attempt to influence public policy and industry strategy. Its output is an inventory of the research published and its principal conclusions.

Who / What: Large communities from Apple, PatientsLikeMe, Wikipedia
Use case: Produce intellectual property or curate knowledge
Description: Can communities create and store technical knowledge? Online communities are one of the largest emerging social phenomena of the last quarter-century. Apple is one of the most prominent nodes, and the algorithms of both Facebook and YouTube exercise significant control on how those communities behave. Communities provide creativity and additional resources that are typically not accessible by normal hierarchical organization. But they’re harder to set up and direct.

Use case: Help people make consumer purchase choices
Description: On Amazon, product displays are governed by democratic user votes that guide the visualization of items when searching or filtering by “customer rating,” but ultimately the hierarchical Amazon category management can decide to delist the product.

Who / What: General pattern recognition through AI, etc
Use case: Reward worthwhile content and penalize spam or fake inputs
Description: Use machine learning to identify participants who are worth rewarding; to detect spam or fake inputs; to identify structures in high-volume process flows, etc. These can either trigger an automated response or be passed on to a human (or a network) for validation.

Use case: Help share knowledge across technicians
Description: Xerox Eureka community helped share knowledge across technicians. One of the first crowdsourced technical community forums in the world.

Use case: Access super forecasters insights
Description: Situations where data sets are insufficient for machines to operate independently. Swarm AI predictions; computing likelihood of human predictions; Early Warning Project to predict mass atrocities. Initially driven by University of Pennsylvania to support IARPA (US intelligence community’s equivalent to DARPA).

Use case: Improve farming
Description: Farming peer-sharing, decision-making platform for small farmers. Exchange of practices, dynamically evolving as new conditions emerge

Use case: Industrialize the finding, improving, and sharing of valuable knowledge
Description: Many consulting firms have communities of practice that form around appointed leaders and serve as watering holes for consultants. However, in this case, the firm uses those nodes as deliberate actors of a tightly knit learning platform enabling the reskilling of tens of thousands of employees. An important element of this infrastructure is the exoskeleton of resources that helps the knowledge nodes to scale. Knowledge management curators, community managers, and advanced analytics that feed the nodes with the latest information about learning patterns and learner experience diagnostics, nodes obtain a rich feedback loop from the system and redirect the execution accordingly.

Use case: Discuss and share knowledge
Description: While not fully managed, these communities benefit from infrastructure and rules that a third party has created. For example, LinkedIn has interest groups that connect people with shared knowledge.

Use case: Find environmental solutions
Description: Ubuntoo is a Service provider that brings together experts and knowledge, focused on environmental sustainability innovation.

Use case: Link large producers directly with pooled groups of consumers
Description: Pinduoduo enables groups of consumers to pool their purchases of farm products and connect directly with farmers and distributors to obtain better price and service, and ultimately better efficiency of the agricultural value chain. Hundreds of millions of people use it today. During the Coronavirus outbreak, which affected traditional wholesale distribution networks, Pinduoduo helped farmers sell perishable stock.

Use case: Apply image recognition software to monitor environmental changes
Description: Grevy’s Zebra Trust has the Wild Me platform to support volunteer and scientists rallies in a wildlife conservancy area. The emerging risk that these platforms need to manage is that they may inadvertently give poachers a way to find animals. Authentication and identity control can be a solution, not unlike in other parts of the web.

Use case: Use citizen Observatories projects to monitor agricultural developments
Description: Expanding on GEOSS (Global Earth Observation System of Systems), the Citizen Observatories projects are funded by the European Union. One of them is GROW (soil-moisture citizen observatory) aimed at climate change and including scientists, NGOs, communities and individuals. Computer vision sifts through mixed-source (people, machines) imagery from both people and machines to enable better agricultural decisions at OneSoil.ai.

Use case: Create maps and correct computer-created maps
Description: Europe’s BlackShore.eu uses gamified crowdsourcing to create maps; it operates in a similar space as OpenStreetMap

Who / What: Nippon Foundation and GEBCO Seabed project
Use case: Crowdsource and bot-source maps
Description: The Nippon Foundation and GEBCO Seabed project, launched in 2017, has by now mapped over 10% of the Earth’s oceanic floors. The next phase will include crowdsourcing of data by appending echo- sounding equipment to all sorts of vessels, based on their routes. Along similar lines, swarms of bots could possibly one day act as sensor networks canvassing larger spaces in a dynamic, adaptable manner.

Use case: Discover related information in text
Description: Identifying the words that describe the space being searched (the semantic network that delineates ontologies e.g. words that are ideally MECE - mutually exclusive and hopefully collectively exhaustive) can be done either heuristically by asking experts to map out the words and clustering them in groups, or even analytically by extracting so-called “entities” by using R or Python NLTK - or more specialized entity visualizers like DisplaCy - to identify words recurrence in typical content.

Use case: Combine human- and machine-sourced text, images, audio
Description: Developed in Qatar, the Crisis Computing group combines multiple sources of text and image data, as well as audio streams, both crowd and machine sourced – in the case of “First Alert” system it uses them to highlight potential crises early. Elsewhere, Dataminr.com combines multiple sources of text and image data, as well as audio streams, both crowd and machine sourced – in the case of “First Alert” system it uses them to highlight potential crises early.

Use case: Analyze natural language through Python
Description: Big data analytics languages like Python are already equipped with extensions to mine social media data. For instance, for Python, Tweepy enables it to connect relatively simply to Twitter’s API and analyze its natural language.

Use case: Enable collaboration for small-scale farmers in Africa
Description: In Africa, Wefarm.co helps millions of small-scale farmers to connect with each other – both through web and SMS - and exchange solutions to their questions.

Use case: Employees learn-by-doing
Description: A marketplace of learning-by-doing opportunities allows learners to consolidate memorization of the learning curriculum by executing small projects in mostly virtual settings. They leverage Microsoft Office 365 including Teams, as well as the core functionality of a Learning Experience Platform (Edcast). The latter also facilitates collaboration by enabling fluid feedback from the learners on specific parts of the curriculum.

Use case: Crowdsource forensics for humanitarian crises
Description: An organizational construct used by Amnesty International which uses its volunteers in Amnesty Decoders, for instance in Decode Darfur which asked participants to identify destroyed areas in the settlements of Darfur using satellite images. Salient characteristics of Amnestty Decoders are: a) annotated data sets created by crowds; b) clustering of human language inputs; c) automated translations; d) automated classification of visual objects. A specific use case is "Troll Patrol" that targets social media misinformation and obfuscation.

Use case: Foster peer-to-peer community of developing-economy farmers
Description: More than a million people use Wefarm.co in Kenya and Uganda, with over 40,000 questions answered every day. Using the technology platform is very simple and is also possible through SMS for those who don’t have access to internet. Interestingly, natural language processing is utilized to facilitate the exchanges in three regional languages in addition to English.

Use case: Deliver insightful media coverage
Description: Journalist and entrepreneur Azeem Azhar’s Exponential View media source, which includes a podcast in collaboration with Harvard Business Review, is synergistic with a newsletter as well as a community of thought leaders run on Slack. The three elements reinforce each other.

Use case: Answer coding questios and share knowledge
Description: StackOverflow is an independent, open community for anyone that codes, with the joint objective to get answers to the toughest coding questions, share knowledge with coworkers in private (and find a job, which acts as a powerful motivator). Other software vendors have been collaboration communities for many years, such as SAP Community Network.

Use case: Engage with networks of people through bots
Description: Large groups of people can and increasingly will be initially engaged by bots, that can execute a simplified yet human-like conversation with the targets, taking an example from recruitment campaigns that have started utilizing such tools (e.g. Kriya.ai, Talkpush).

Use case: Heed to microsegmented preferences in entertainment and creation
Description: Intelligent systems can create product designs on Etsy.com, or a new algorithm on Kaggle to predict your Netflix movie preferences. Or use generative design where machine learning-based algorithms help create and filter dozens of options that humans, either individually or in groups, enhance and decide upon.

Use case: Enable counterterrorism activities
Description: Proactively bring pro-social voices into the community forums. An example of this is Google Jigsaw, which for instance was used to build anti-terrorism narratives leveraging AdWords and YouTube in an effort to disrupt ISIS’ recruitment networks

Use case: Harness an open-access genomics database (USA)
Description: GenBank, an open-access repository of genome sequences run by America’s National Institutes of Health. It was used for the first analyses of the genomic sequences of Covid-19. [Source: Azeem Azhar, "Exponential"]

Use case: Harness an open-access genomics and health database (UK)
Description: UK Biobank collates the medical and genomic data of 500,000 people. Each has consented to researchers using their data to better understand and prevent serious disease. And any legitimate researcher can access this resource. By 2020, more than 20,000 researchers were doing so. [Source: Azeem Azhar, "Exponential"]

Use case: Improve cities' procurement processes
Description: Citimart is a platform that helps cities to get more innovative in their procurement processes, by enlarging the vendor and subject matter experts’ pools, and enables the sharing of outcomes and learnings from respective implementations.

Use case: Label datasets for AI by frontline responders, human-in-the-loop technology development
Description: Ensuring human oversight of algorithms after deployment can help to identify and correct these errors in a timely manner. For this project, a group of volunteers from the Montgomery County Community Emergency Response Team (MCERT) helped to check and correct labels assigned by the AI classifier. This participatory approach, known as human-in-the-loop, was used to verify the classifications being made by the system and correct any mistakes in real time. The process also resulted in a novel image dataset with expert labels of damage to further train the algorithm and improve its accuracy during future deployments.During the two-week period that followed the landfall of Hurricane Dorian, the system was deployed to collect and filter social media images. Approximately 160,000 images were tagged as relevant by the system, with ~26,000 of these containing some damage content. All images that the system ranked as severe or mild were sent for human validation. Using a dedicated web-interface for microtasking to support humanitarian efforts, local domain experts from MCERT examined this evolving sample, performing a two-stage verification. They first checked if the image contained damage content and then assigned a severity level based on a predetermined taxonomy. The research team also developed a detailed tutorial to ensure that all labellers were approaching the task in a consistent manner. The corrections made by the community responders helped to identify common types of errors made by the algorithm. For example, the AI system struggled with images taken from afar or in low-light and poor resolution settings. Isolating this weakness helped the technical team to develop targeted improvements and the response teams to better understand the potential added value of the AI tool for their operations during crisis response. (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Facilitate economic policy development
Description: Morocco utilized a collective intelligence method in 2019 to inform its economic policy and generally its development. The process involved social media outreaches and input, coupled with workshops with multiple underserved constituency.

Use case: Simplify use of crowdsourced genomics databases
Description: DNAnexus simplifies and strengthen the access to the UK Biobank database, which is one of the largest genomics databases in the world. UK BioBank has collected longitudinal clinical data from more than 500,000 people and is expected to quadruple its size in the next five years (the equivalent of adding a century of high-definition video footage). DNAnexus uses Amazon Web Services.

Use case: Identiy creative talent through NFTs
Description: LootNFT.io uses non-fungible tokens (NFTs) for auctions of virtual art.

Use case: Harness the models of thousands of data scientists for hedge funds
Description: Numerai serves up obfuscated data (homomorphic encryption) to over 7,000 data scientists who feed back AI models to predict the stock market, and get paid in digital currencies when the trades are successful. It aims at creating meta models by crowdsourcing models that predict stock market dynamics better.

Use case: Enable citizens to increase transparency, accountability, and community effectiveness
Description: www.mysociety.org is an NGO based in the UK whose technology is used in dozens of countries, to enable citizens so they can keep their institutions more accountable and informed. They do so by improving the user experience in doing things that democratic institutions are mandated to do, but often don't make it easy to happen - such as alerting public authorities or public officials about local problems, or requesting information from them.

Use case: Create a professional network for project-based work
Description: Polywork enables users to log in professional activities with more granularity than what's possible with established professional networks. The objective is to help workers (and demand for them) find each other based on a more fluid, gig-friendly, taxonomy.

Use case: Curated, targeted, non-noisy social media
Description: Serif.space is a social network that is meant for slow, thoughtful, carefully curated experiences, built by and for a small percentage of the population - the queer community.

Use case: Consolidate agricultural data
Description: Agrimetrics is a website and data tools to find, manage, and monetise food, farming, and environmental data.

Use case: Open-source agricultural seeds breeding and distribution
Description: Bioleft is a community of open source seed exchange and breeding to offer solutions to the challenges of agriculture. In their words: "Bioleft is a community that builds an open seed exchange and breeding network to offer alternative solutions to the challenges of agriculture. Based on collective intelligence, open knowledge, agreements and solidarity, we develop social and technological innovations that allow the exchange of information. We link local and scientific knowledge to enhance the role of farmers in seed conservation and breeding. In this way they generate a greater availability of biodiverse and resilient seeds, considered as a commons."

Use case: Improve policing
Description: "On a typical day in the United States, police officers make more than 50,000 traffic stops. Our team is gathering, analyzing, and releasing records from millions of traffic stops by law enforcement agencies across the country. Our goal is to help researchers, journalists, and policymakers investigate and improve interactions between police and the public." (source: https://openpolicing.stanford.edu/)

Use case: Use mobile devices for improving policing
Description: Android application called CopCast – turning smartphones into police body-worn cameras in Brazil. https://igarape.org.br/en/apps/smart-policing/

Use case: Multi-source data about air warfare
Description: Monitoring and assessing civilian harm from airpower-dominated international military actions. Seeking transparency and accountability from belligerents, and advocating on behalf of affected non-combatants. Archiving open-source casualty reports, and military claims by nations. Based on social media and volunteer triangulation.

Use case: Track apparel supply chain abuse
Description: The Open Apparel Registry exists to improve human rights and environmental conditions in and around factories and facilities by opening up supply chain data as a free, public good. When everyone working in global supply chains enjoys equal access to quality, open-licensed data, it leads to more sustainable and equitable outcomes for the most vulnerable communities affected by the apparel sector.

Use case: Detect hate speech
Description: Tooling enabling the sensing and assessment of hate speech, with a combination of machine and experts.

Use case: Collate data about the planet's resources
Description: Resource Watch features hundreds of data sets all in one place on the state of the planet’s resources and citizens. Users can visualize challenges facing people and the planet, from climate change to poverty, water risk to state instability, air pollution to human migration, and more.

Use case: Analyze visually large natural language text
Description: Enables the text analysis on large corpora, for instance to find connected topics and summarize the relationships visually. https://iscpif.fr/gargantext/

Use case: Analyze knowledge from wikis
Description: Enable the analysis of the text and the relationships between authors over time

Use case: Share water data
Description: Promote knowledge sharing and advance collaborative water stewardship

Use case: Simplify citizen science data
Description: Anecdata is used by hundreds of individuals and organizations to gather and access citizen science observations and provides a platform to easily collect, manage, and share their citizen science data.

Use case: Simplify citizen science data
Description: The custom smartphone apps for Android & IOS and the interactive map are a complete modern toolset for projects for Citizen Science, smart city apps and similar uses.

Use case: Provide crowd generated data overlays on maps
Description: Cognicity (city level input), Terrifica.eu (climate change signals), curio.xyz (local community tree preservation) help add valuable, crowdsourced data on top of geospatial data.

Use case: Crowdsource insect pollination analysis
Description: Users use the platform to make observations, post them to the community, and analyze them. The objective is to better understand pollination patterns and related risks (France)

Use case: Crowdsource monitoring of environmental justice
Description: Global geospatial and qualitative data about environmental abuses in local communities, mapped by citizens and researchers.

Use case: Crowdsource bioacustic deforestation data
Description: Biodiversity loss through illegal poaching of animals is also causing deforestation. Rainforest connection is helping to direct limited resources on the ground, e.g. deploying park rangers to the locations that they are needed. Finally bioacoustic monitoring is providing a unique dataset for local ecologists, helping them to improve outcomes for the reintroduction of key species. https://rfcx.org/our_work

Use case: Harness citizen science for detecting light pollution
Description: Globe at Night is an international citizen-science campaign to raise public awareness of the impact of light pollution by inviting citizen-scientists to measure & submit their night sky brightness observations.

Use case: Monitor algae's evolution
Description: HABscope - citizen science project by NOAA in US to monitor algal blooms using low cost hardware. (Source: Nesta UK) https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0218489

Use case: Use an AR app for participatory greening of cities
Description: The app is pre-loaded with examples, enables citizens to simulate greenery placements in their cities, and engage with planner

Use case: Build citizen assemblies
Description: AppCivist is a free platform that lets users design and build their own Assemblies with modular components to organize democratic action.

Use case: Crowdsource the annotation of a citizen discourse corpus
Description: Granddebat.fr offers to the public the ability to weigh in on many social issues, by providing plain-text answers. To help the analysis, this project enlists the help of thousands of people who tag the contributions.

Use case: Map social media's political ads
Description: This website identifies and visualizes political ads on Facebook for the purpose of monitoring and analyzing them

Use case: Analyze microbiome data in cities' shared infrastructure
Description: Metasub's objective is to "build a molecular profile of cities around the globe to improve their design, functionality, and impact on health. Public transportation systems represent the densest interaction space for millions of people each day, and yet, there is little known about the dynamics of the microbiome and metagenomics profile on these surfaces, and most importantly, how these dynamics and our interactions with these surfaces can impact an individual’s health, as well as the health of a city." Citizen scientists participate in the samplings. Its results are open sourced.

Use case: Safely crowdsource health data
Description: Switzerland based Midata has created an architecture that allows individuals to donate their health data to contribute to research, while retaining control on their privacy.

Use case: Redesign healthcare by surfacing health communities ideas
