Description: "Contributing towards care provision reform. opencare aims at studying on what constitutes best practice in the field of community based collective intelligence projects in the field of care provision, and on how these solutions might be integrated in national social and health care systems. The opencare consortium will develop a software stack to monitor and assist collective intelligence social dynamics in online communities. We develop software to help the community make sense by identifying points of consensus and controversy, summarizing, and structuring arguments."

Use case: Facilitate the repurposing of drugs
Description: CureAccelerator supports “proof of concept” research repurposing drugs, devices and nutriceuticals already approved for human use. On CureAccelerator, funders have direct access to repurposing research, researchers can post ideas and connect with peers and funding, and clinicians can contribute their experience of off-label use in need of validation.

Use case: Inventory critical medical devices
Description: This database contains information on more than 120,000 Recalls, Safety Alerts and Field Safety Notices about medical devices distributed worldwide. The information connects with medical device companies and their subsidiaries. Compiled by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ) and 58 media partners in 36 countries during our year-long Implants File investigation, the database fills a critical information void. The data is drawn from both public sources and responses to Freedom of Information requests.

Use case: Detect disease outbreak
Description: Epicore uses HealthMap in combination with a network of local expert to understand disease outbreaks (source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Track epidemics
Description: This platform offers detailed information for over 120 distinct pathogens, including a profile, history and up-to-date disease statistics validated by experts. (Source: Nesta UK)

Use case: Verify online media facts
Description: A team of fact checkers prioritizes statement made by influential sources and posts the assessment online, ready to be picked up and shared by social media and other information platforms on the web.

Use case: Verify online video content
Description: Crowd-based intelligence, such as Open Source Intelligence (OSINT), is facilitated by tools like InVid, Google Reverse Image Search, TinEye, RevEye, Yandex, Baidu, Google Lens, Exiftool, Redfin, Amnesty Video verification, and Trulymedia.

Use case: Find personal pictures posted online
Description: Existing pictures of a person can be used to find other places on the web where that person's picture have been posted. Open source intelligence uses this method. Privacy concerns are obvious.

Use case: Share with neighbors
Description: UK based Streetbank is a platform that helps neighbors share assets, tools, skills between each other; and dispose of unwanted items with others.

Use case: Use open-source energy data to improve forecasts
Description: In 2022, the International Energy Agency (IEA) announced that it would make much of its data sets open for the public to access and use for modeling, in the hope of improving cost and availability predictions among others. This is an important step in enabling communities to study countermeasures to climate change. The agency is funded mostly by governments, and has been criticized in the past because its predictions of renewable costs (particularly solar) systematically overshot the actual outcomes, making the renewables transition feel in some cases more expensive than it would actually be.

Use case: Complementing historical meteorological records
Description: "Ed Hawkins, a climate scientist at the University of Reading in England, put out a call for help transcribing more than 65,000 handwritten logs of monthly rainfall, spanning three centuries, from across Britain and Ireland. The writing in the records was too irregular to be read by machine; human eyes were needed. More than 16,000 people answered Dr. Hawkins’s request, and together they chewed through the task in a little over two weeks. That was [...] during Britain’s first coronavirus lockdown. [By early 2022], the nation’s weather agency, the Met Office, [had] processed 3.3 million data points from the transcribed pages and added them to its national rainfall statistics, enriching the official record with many more observations and extending it back to 1836." (Source: The New York Times)

Use case: Identifying misleading fast-food marketing online
Description: In order to combat disinformation and improving the nutritional education level, UK social innovation consulting Nesta organized a community of teens so they could detect potentially dangerous marketing practices.

Use case: Understand weather events through crowdsourcing
Description: Dust storms have been occurring with record-breaking frequency in 2019, according to data collected from Australian citizen-science DustWatch.

Use case: Crowdsource Predictors of Residential Electric Energy Usage
Description: Residential electricity users are able to contribute valuable consumption hypotheses and drivers that can inform modeling.

Use case: Improve turn directions on maps
Description: Crowdsourced data from actual turns at intersections, combined with other map data, can improve and update existing street maps.

Use case: Improve crop variety adaptation against climate change
Description: Farmers acting as citizen scientists have shown to be able to recommend actions that lead to better yield in the presence of climate change. Source: https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.1813720116

Use case: Monitor water data
Description: The US government's EPA's Collaborative seeks to expand activities related to the Internet of Water (IoW), a vision for improving data flow between typically fragmented water sectors, in order to proactively engage citizen science in non-governmental organizations (NGOs). Active facilitation by the Collaborative has allowed for seamless integration of water data into the IoW technical framework, maximizing the potential for data to be included in public policy and community decision-making.

Use case: Use robust open-source geocoding data
Description: OpenCageData consolidates open source geocoding data and makes its API commercially available in a way that simplifies access and provides quality control. The result is qualitatively comparable to traditional proprietary data (like Google's). This example is somewhat analogous to companies like RedHat have done with open source Linux code.

Use case: Protect kelp forests
Description: KelpWatch.org maps kelp forests and their evolution with geospatial data, to help organizations protect those ecosystems as they're particularly effective at sequesting carbon but they are endangered by the rise of water temperature.

Use case: Build a community in your inbox
Description: Superhive simplifies the user experience of participating in a community by automating the aggregation and sharing of simple requests made by community members in a periodic email newsletter. The upside is that user don't need to leave their email environment to interact.

Use case: Find beautiful places
Description: http://scenicornot.datasciencelab.co.uk/ crowdsources opinions about the beauty of places in the UK, by asking users to simply rate the beauty of a picture on a website. The data has been combined with geospatial data to evaluate the scenic beauty of places.

Use case: Design new technology inspired by nature
Description: Biomimicry.org inventories natural designs that have the potential to inform human design of new engineering concepts, hence fostering new possibilities for "interspecies intelligence".

Use case: Make people fitter
Description: Fitness app Strava has a number of social features that motivate users to come back. For instance, members can suggest routes for running or cycling, and encourage each other, particularly in a local area.

Use case: Incentivize climate transition
Description: GoodCarbon offers access to existing and emerging natural climate solution projects and related carbon streams across soil and soil and forest ecoysytems. Its platform intends to bring transparency and liquidity to this part of the carbon offset market.
